post.creator: Robert Lawrence
post.title: The Exponential Performance of Nathan’s Hot Dog Eating Contest Winners
post.content:encoded:
Will we ever see a contestant break 80 HDBs in 10 minutes?

In 1916 on Coney Island, four immigrants once had an argument about who was most patriotic. They settled that argument by having a contest to see who could eat the most hot dogs at a Nathan’s Hot Dog stand, giving birth to the Nathan’s Hot Dog Eating Contest that has continued every year since. So the story goes anyway.

Mythology is nothing new to this strange competition, which really does have a long history, even if it may not go all the way back to 1916. The rules are simple: the contestants must eat as many hot dogs and buns (known colloquially as “HDBs”) in 10 minutes — or sometimes 12 minutes or whatever is decided beforehand. And beverages or condiments are allowed to help wash it down.

According to Wikipedia, the contest winners could be expected to cram down about 10 hot dogs and buns each year. In the 1990s it began to get a bit more competitive as winners were hitting the 20 mark.

But then in 2001, a thin-framed 23-year old from Japan who stood 5'8" stepped onto the scene and blew all precedents out of the water as he put down 50 hot dogs. His name was Takeru Kobayashi, and using a technique that became known as the “Kobayashi Shake,” he continued winning the contest for the next 5 years at about the same level of performance.

In 2007, Kobayashi was dethroned by someone who most people in the world of competitive eating would consider to be the G.O.A.T. today: Joey “Jaws” Chesnut. Since then, Chesut has lost only one contest, when he fell to Matt Stonie in 2015. So far he has maxed out at 76 hot dogs and buns, and is determined to someday break through the 80 HDB ceiling.

Defiantly, Kobayashi has not participated in the Nathan’s contest since 2009 due to a dispute with the governing organization, Major League Eating. And in 2010, he was arrested for interrupting the competition from the sidelines as Chesnut chomped his way to victory. As I said, this contest is rife with mythology and that is just one example. Here are several more.

One thing that is certain though is that Kobayash and Chesnut have taken competitive hot dog eating to another realm. I’ve attempted to illustrate that in the data visualization below, which shows the winning HDB counts each year since 1979 when the contest began being held regularly on Independence Day. This is based on record compiled in Wikipedia, as there isn’t an official data source on this as far as I know.

One interesting note is the year 1984. Not only is that the only year since 1979 when someone representing a country other than the U.S. or Japan has won, it is also the only year since then that a woman has won the competition. Representing Germany, Birgit Felden ate 9.5 HBDs in 10 minutes. Since 2011, women have competed in their own division, where the winners nowadays usually put away about 40 HDBs.
